div.p: THE FOOL Turn'd Critick: A COMEDY:
As it was Acted at the Theatre-Royall. By His Majesties Servants.
LONDON, Printed for Iames Magnes and Richard Bentley, at the Post-Office in Russel-Street in Covent-Garden, 1678.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: HE who comes hither with design to hiss,
And with a bum revers'd, to whisper Miss,
To comb a Perriwig, or to shew gay cloathes,
Or to vent Antique non-sence with new oaths,
Our Poet welcomes as the Muses friend;
For hee'l by irony each Play commend.
Next these we welcome such as briskly dine,
At Locket's, at Gissord's, or with Shataline.
Swell'd with Pottage, and the Burgundian Grape,
They hither come to take a kindly nap.
In these our Poet don't conceive much harm;
For they pay well, and keep our benches warm.
And though scarce half awake, some Playes they dam,
They do't by Whole-sail; not by Ounce, and Dram.
But when fierce Criticks get them in their clutch,
They're crueller then the Tirannick Dutch.
And with more Art, do dislocate each Scene,
Then in Amboyna they the limbs of men.
They wrack each line, and every word unknit,
As if they'd find away to cramp all Wit.
They are the terror of all adventurers here,
The very objects of their hate and fear,
And like rude Common-wealths they still are knit
'Gainst English Plays, the Monarchyes of wit,
They invade Poetique Lisence, and still rail
At Plays, to which in duty they should vail.
Yet still the' infest this Coast to fish for jests,
To supplement their Wits at City feasts.
Thus much for Criticks: to the more generous Wit,
Our Poet Frankly, does each Scene submit;
And begs your kind Allience to ingage
Those Hogen interlopers of the Stage.

div.head: ACT. I.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: PIsh, never doubt it man, thou shalt enjoy her;
Give me thy hand, I say thou shalt: a man of thy
Perfections, and despair of gaining a slight woman?
Come, come, no more, Thou shalt possess her Bernard.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Prithee Frank,
Leave off thy Railery, thy mirth's unseasonable;
I am not pleas'd to hear thee flatter me
With hopes of what thou never canst perform,
Especially this way.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: I last thou a Faith?
Canst thou believe the thing thou feest atchiev'd?
Give credit to an act is done and finish'd before thy Eyes?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Yes sure, I could do that.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Why then I say once more aloud to thee,
Thou shalt enjoy this woman▪ I will, to do thee
A kindness, be an honourable Procurer.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Ha! Procurer!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Nay, nay, mistake me not, I mean I'le get her for thee.
Procurer, or Match-maker, its all one,
The word has several meanings.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Though I know thy vanity to be such, that in
Thy thoughts thou couldst do wonders, but
Thy power, barren as Earth on Rocks of
Unknown height; yet in thy words lies something
that is pleasing, though far from my belief,
Thou canst perform it.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Try me, and if I do not.—

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: How canst thou think to do't, Thou know'st her not,
Art unacquainted with her Family, Friends and Relations.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: I grant I am Sir— But Heaven be prais'd I'm
Owner of a certain confidence, that never fails
To usher my acquaintance with any of that Sex.
The least thing that of a thousand.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: But thou art wild, and wavering in thy Temper,
Apt to run out into Extravagancies, unfit for her
To hear, much less commend. Canst thou be serious Frank.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Canst thou be wise— serious—
Ud's death, dost take her for an Abbess?
Or one o'th Zealots at Amsterdam?
That thou dost School me thus— hark, hark,
Bernard, Were she a Widdow zealously devout,
One doting on some brawny suburb Parson,
That preaches, following him the way to Heaven;
A mess of phrases, serious, loud and chiming, might
Work upon her Spirit: But a Girl who is as
Thou describ'st her, free and airy, sanguine of her
Complexion, young and healthy, a serious speech
To her, is like a long Grace to one of an eager
Appetite, fruitless, as 'tis distastful.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: But prithee how— what wilt thou say to her?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: I know not yet— but do not doubt me, I'le do
Thy business; never fear it Bernard: Thou hast,
I thank thee, supply'd me with money, and thereby crost
My miserable Fathers purpose of marrying me
To an old Widow here i'th City.— And to gratifie
Thee, this Woman shall be thine— and by my means.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: A strange confidence!
But perhaps— he knows something of her— That
Makes him thus presume— I am resolv'd to try—
Well Frank, this once I'le trust Thee— I am to
Night invited by her Father to Supper; Thou shalt
Go with me; and if thou canst perform this,
Thou art my Friend indeed.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And thou shalt find me so, Come lets away.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: Is your name Smallwit?

sp.speaker: Small.
sp.l: Iervas Smallwit, Sir. the meanest of your Worships
Humble Servants, One that shall prouder be to kiss
Your hand, then to be crown'd with Laurel by Apollo.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.l: Good Mr. Smallwit!
No Flowers of Rhetorick to me, your stock I fear
Will be exhausted soon enough,— by him there,
Without ●is loss on me, you are commended to me
By a good Friend of mine, Old Sir Formal Ancient.

sp.speaker: Small.
sp.p: He is my Patron Sir.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.l: He sends me word, you have your Tropes and Figures,
Your Syllogisms, Epithetes and Phrases, I could
Have nam'd e'm right in my young days, ready by heart,
And that you can accost, Repartee, come on, draw off,
Retreat, and hold discourse even with the best of
Our Tongue Combatants.

sp.speaker: Small.
sp.p: I should do something Sir, I've studied long for't.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.l: And that you can with fair becoming Grace,
And modish cringes vouch your gallantry
'Gainst any Squire of the Pantofle
Within the Kings Dominion.

sp.speaker: Small.
sp.p: I hope I can Sir.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.l: Very well— I'm glad on't.
I'm very glad your skill is so unquestion'd,
There's one will want it all— and more I doubt not.
Come hither Sir.

sp.speaker: Small.
sp.p: Is this the Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.l: The same Sir,— 'tis my Heir, the only he
That ever call'd me Father;
And though he seems to have but a course outside,
He has a cunning Headpiece— a shrewd pate;
His inner Rooms are furnisht well Sir,
Take my word; besides, he keeps good Company
That edifie him much, good Singing, Dancing, Swearing,
Jovial Company; Then has seen all the new Plays;
And you'l find him a Proficient.

sp.speaker: Small.
sp.p: It were a sin to doubt it Sir.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.l: Yet though he be well furnisht thus by nature,
He has not the Town virtues, Talk and Impudence;
No modish Gallantry to gloss his parts, and make e'm shine,

sp.speaker: Small.
sp.p: Sir fear not, hee'l soon learn.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.l: I should be griev'd else, troth I should Sir.
Now I would have you Sir as you are stil'd
The Mercury, nay the Apollo of this age
To teach him these indowments— I would have him
Learn how to Court his Mistress, huff a Rival
That crosses his designs, quarrel with Bullies,
And pick a Wench up with alacrity.
Then to see Plays, and how to firut i'th Pit,
Manage his Combe, swear modishly Gad damme;
Talk aloud, to make his parts be noted.

sp.speaker: Small.
sp.l: Never doubt Sir,
He shall be soon instructed with these Rules.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.l: And when the Play's begun, I'de have him sit
In the Wits Corner, play the Critick, hiss
At any thing he do's not understand:
Be the Scene ne're so witty— That's no matter,
'Tis Modish and Gentile.

sp.speaker: Small.
sp.l: He shall not fail Sir:
Nay he shall hold a parley with the Wits:
Propound and answer things beyond his knowledge,
And yet come off with credit.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.l: Shall he faith?
Shall he come off with credit?— do but that Sir,
Bring him but off with credit, and you bless me;
And I'le not be ungrateful— see here's 50 Guineys;
This as an Earnest of my future Bounty:
And if he come off, and as thou sayst, with credit,
A hundred more shall pay obeysance to Thee!
Tim, come hither Tim, how dost Thou like this Gentleman?
Ha, prithee tell me,— Come be not so bashful.
You two must be acquainted.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Faith Sir,— I like him very well— But—

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: But— pish no Buts— hee'l make a Courtier Tim.

sp.speaker: Small.
sp.l: Ah, do not fear it Sir, The Squire and I
Shall soon be intimate, wee'l be Chamber-fellows,
Be Drunk together, Sing and Roar together,
Ramble till two i'th Morning, and then Slip
Into some private Lodging in the Parke,
And get a Wench or two.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Withall my heart:
A very pleasant fellow; I like him Sir extreamly.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.l: Nay, doubt him not Sir, he is cock oth' game,
I told you, you should find him a true Winelove:
He had it from his Father,— ay in my capring days:
I would have Wrestled, Leapt, Run, pitch'd the Bar;
And kist a sound Wench in a frosty morning,
With any Squire in Northampton-shire:
But now, I must consess my Ages Autumn,
Bafflles my weak endeavours.

sp.speaker: Small.
sp.p: Oh, not so Sir.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.l: Faith 'tis very true— but 'tis no matter,
Be you but careful to instruct my Son;
'Tis all I wish— in him my youth shall flourish:
And be you sure Tim, to observe his Doctrine,
Follow his Precepts with a greedy Eare;
And let me see you strut it in the Streets,
Display thy Garniture, Hat, Curl'd Shaddrew
With my bully Gamester, in White-Fryers.
Ne're doubt the means, Thou shalt have Money store,
I have been scraping it this 50 year:
And thou shalt never want that my Boy.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I will do what you please Sir.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.l: Why, I would have you Tim, to be a Fine Courtier,
A Jauntee, Modish follower of the times,
Hah wilt thou strive?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Yes Sir, I will strive;
I'le be as Impudent as you please to have me.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: Wilt thou?— why, well said- ha, what think you now Sir▪

sp.speaker: Small.
sp.p: A pregnant Wit, believe me Sir.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: And Sir, to show my duty more— I will be drunk
Very often, lye a Bed all day, and rise at midnight;
I'le get a Wench Sir, and if you think good a Clap,
And then I shall be sure to be o'th fashion.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.l: Now by Honour rarely thought upon,
A Clap indeed is Modish.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I Sir, 'tis so,

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.l: Wee'l talk further of this point within:
I must entreat you Sir to dine with me,
Pray let us be Familiar.

sp.speaker: Small.
sp.p: I am in troth too bold Sir.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: Fye not a jot— come lets in— Tim follow your T●●●●.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

div.head: SCENE III. Hall.
div.stage: Enter Sir Formal Ancient, and Penelope.

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.l: Daughter I say, be wise; these are ill times,
And we should therefore be more provident:
I do not like this Bernard, that frequents
My house, and your company; Daughter I say,
I do not like him.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Why Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.l: Nay, nay, I know not that; yet to satisfie you,
His Father was a roaring Cavalier,
Apeaching Raskal, that betray'd our Faction:
H' had like to hang'd my Uncle; and for that trick
I hate the generation: Yet to say truth,
It is a Courteous Varlet, and a my conscience,
Would stake his Life for his Friend: but what then,
His Lineage all were Knaves, conforming Rogue's;
Fellowes that strain'd their throats for a free state,
And for that cause I hate 'em.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: You are my▪ Father Sir, and 'twould be thought
Great folly in me to question your Commands,
Much less deny 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.l: How, deny 'em!
Dare you deny my commmands.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Sir, you mistake, I alwayes meant to obey
What you and Heaven should impose upon me.

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.l: Didst thou not say at first,
Thou would'st deny my just Commands.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: No Sir, I said 'twas folly in me to deny 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.p: And dost no doubt dissemble with me,

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Believe me Sir, I do not, I am now
As I was ever, ready to obey you,
In any just Command.

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.l: Thou art my Daughter, and should'st practise duty;
Therefore I say once more, and with a parent like authority,
I do not like this Bernard, therefore Discard him;
See that my doors close lockt oppose his entrance:
I have no house-room for him, tell him so,
How now!

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, there's one Sir Peter Winelove at the three Crane Tavern, desires your Company about Earnest Business.

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.l: Go tell him I come— I guess his Business, Exit Servant
He has a Son lately come out 'oth Country;
And wants a Wife— Daughter go you to your Closet,
Fall on your knees, and pray my hopes may be successful:
There is a Blessing coming, and I'le work for't

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Such Blessings I expect not, nor desire:
— when 'ere I marry, or intend it, my Father
I see, by this Carriage to Bernard, will oppose it,
If it suites not with his liking, I'me vext;
Extreamly vext at my ill Fortune, and though
I have no passion for this Bernard, he do's
Deserve it: And it might have been my Fate, as
Well as now 'tis his: Well— I'le leave all to
Time; the Dice may turn, and I may yet be happy.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Madam, there's a Lady, accompanied with a Gentleman
Below is come to visit you.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Wait on 'em in. Exit Servant. Enter Franck Amorous and Lucia
Dearest Madam, a thousand, thousand Welcomes;
To what happy accident am I obliged,
That obliged me with your presence.

sp.speaker: Lue.
sp.l: To no accident; I came to Sit and talk with you:
Or if thou like the Weather, lets take a turn in
The Parke: I have been so melancholly since
My Brother went out of the Town.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Is not that Franck Amorous? Heavens! 'tis he,
— how came he with her Aside.
Madam, what Gentleman is that?

sp.speaker: Lue.
sp.p: Why, don't you know him?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: No, that's strange, I met him at the door▪
And hearing me ask for you, pretended business,
And desir'd the favour to conduct me to you.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Business with me? What this should mean I know not.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Madam, although ' its my unhappiness to be a stranger
To you, and consequently to be destitute of what
Would make me blest, could I obtain it— your
Acquaintance, yet emboldned by the Cause, I
Presume to tell you that I have Business.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: With me?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Madam, with you.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Heaven grant it be to'th purpose: Madam I beg▪
Your excuse for a Minutes Conference— pray
Declare it Sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I have a Friend that Loves you▪

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Well Sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: That dyes for you.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Not unlikely.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: And to this Friend, have I engaged my honour,
That you shall.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: What I

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Receive his Love— permit him to enjoy you,
The only Cure I know.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: But whence Sir springs your Confidence in my consent,
That you durst promise this?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Why, Faith no Confidence in you, but in my own
Ability, made me do't: Besides, the knowledge
I have that a woman of honour, as you are, or
Would at least be thought, could not refuse so
Fervent an address, when offered by so brave
A Gentleman; especially when urged by perswasions.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I will not trouble my self with reproving your vanity;
That were a fruitless work, but I desire to know,
Who 'tis that is thus pain'd— pray Sir, what is he?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Why, Faith a man, that were a Non Parelio,
But that he doats on women— a general fault.
Ye have the Ascendant over us.
This Paper will make all plain;
There you may read his name.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Well I am strangely taken with this Fellow; Aside.
How many Bernards live in him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I cannot much blame Bernard for his choice;
This is no ordinary woman, and therefore not
To be dispis'd: But yonders a Lady, through whose
Vizard— I met an eye that darted fire into me—
What a presence she has: Now would I give a
Million for an invisible hand to snatch away that Mask.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Well Sir, I've read the Letter— and to let you
See, I neither flight the message nor the Bearer:
I'le Write an Answer to it; he may hope
Still, assure him I will do't: In the mean time
I will not fail to commend your fidelity.
Madam, I'le wait upon you instantly, please you to
Permit this Gentleman to keep you Company; I know
Him now, and can assure the general voice of
Fame denotes him Noble.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: So, this has introduced me, and I'le forward:
This must be a rare woman: Bowes to her. She lets fall her Mask, he snatches it up:
How great a reason have I to bliss
Fortune, that by an accident permits my eye,
The view of so much Excellence.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No Excellence Sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: ‛ I faith it is— O cast away that cloud,
That shuts up so much Beauty.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Pray spare your Rhetorick, and let me tell you Sir,
I hate a flatterer,
As I hate the Devil, and would as soon avoid him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: A flatterer Madam, damn him— I hope
You have heard nothing in my words,
That you should take me for flatterer;
I know too much of honour to dissemble.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Pardon me Sir, If I make doubt of that,
You are a man I hope.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I was this morning.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And are yet, doubt not,— if so you may dissemble
By th' charter of your Sex.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: But your known beauty, by all so much admir'd,
Deserves, nor needs no flattery, besides I
Applaud a truth, and that is still allow'd.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: By some I grant it is— and since your searching wit
Has thrust me on Discourse against my will;
I'le let you know my temper.
I hate a man that flatters worse then death;
He that should fawn, and sooth me in my Errour;
I'de shun him, as I would the Pestilence—
I am not made perhaps of the same mould,
That other women are; I do not love to hear
A Fop cry Madam, I vow to gad that smile
Became you sweetly.
No'tis a careless, blunt, and
Manly Carriage that likes me best— Besides
Sir, I think 'tis newer, and more modish.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'Tis a witty Wanton—
There's no way but to wheel about; and begin with
Her in her own Stile— Madam I must confess,
I did mistake your temper; but from henceforth,
You shall perceive I am more given to satyrise,
Then flatter or dissemble.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I am glad on't.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Fortune in this hath been most kind to me, to make
Me worthy of your joy.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Still in that vein— take heed.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I have done Madam— the Divels in me;
I cannot out of my road, though I am punish'd for't.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I doubt not but I am meanly priz'd in your thoughts,
For being thus free.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: No, no, not much for that;— I know your Sexes frailty.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Our frailty.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I your ambition, or call it worse, your pride.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But pray refresh your memory Sir,
Did not you first accost me, did not you long
To break the Ice, and speak to me? come confess.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I long to speak to you, ha, ha, ha, that's fine;
Pray Madam, recollect, peruse your self,
What is there in that face that I should long for?
I think I fit her now. Aside.
— long to speak to you.— That's a good jest i'faith.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: If I mistake, and am indeed so indifferent in your eye,
As you declare I am; you will oblidge your self
To remove from me to some more taking object.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: No Madam, you may do what you please— I have business.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I shall not want intreaty.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'Ds death she's going indeed— Madam, sweet Madam,
What do you mean? Now have I like a Puppy,
Overdone my part, and made her angry— you
Will not go in earnest?

sp.speaker: Luc
sp.p: I use not Sir to jest with strangers.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You know I did this but in obedience to your
Command, far from my own good Temper, Heaven
Knows, and if your mind be changed, and you affect
Another Courtship better— 'tis but wheeling a little
Way about again▪ Madam, I'le be with you presently.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: No Sir, 'tis needless, I am very well satisfied in
The knowledge of your Temper, as I hope you are
Of mine, and am at present very unwilling to
Urge a further tryal.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Then make me so happy to know your Lodging,
That I may have liberty to pay my duty to you,
In requital of this favour.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: That I cannot neither, he that Loves me must seek me;
Perhaps the reward will not be worth the search:
But 'tis my humour Sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Nay, now you are cruel Madam—▪ dsdeath do
You make a Beagle of me, and think I can
Hunt you out, upon the scent? I'faith you
Are too rigorous.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My words are irrevocable, and 'twill be discretion
In you not to urge me further.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I've done, and will be patient— but if I do
Meet you again, as it shall go very hard if I
〈◊〉 〈◊〉 I will— but no matter, let this suffice
At present, I love you beyond thought, and will
Find a time to let you know't at large.

div.stage: Enter Penelope with a Letter written.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Here Sir, 'tis done; I have in this discover'd
My mind to him: And besides, have given him to
Understand how much he is engaged to you:
But let him for a time forbear our house,
It is my fathers pleasure; his mind may alter
And set all right again. Pray tell him so.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Madam, you have oblidg'd us both, and I shall be
Most happy in an imployment to gratifie
This favour; in the mean time, all I can do is to
Acknowledge it, and live your humble servant.
Fair Madam yours— 'dsdeath she'l perceive my
Extafie— Ladies— your servant—

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Well I do love this Fellow, and will
Devise some means that he shall know it;
Come Madam lets abroad.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I am ready to wait on you.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: He has a cunning Tongue, but that I value little: No,
The choice of prudent Judgments I approve;
Honour and virtue, must obtain my Love.

div.trailer: The End of the first Act.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: TO be in Love, is to be mad, and live a phrase,
That rarely sits my present disposition; for
Certainly if I had sense; or any reason left,
I should have kept my self free, at least from Love,
The plague of all mankind.
Sure the Devil, when Providence first
Quicken'd men with life, mingled this amorous
Poyson with their blood, as a continual torment.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Dear Frank!— what return'd already?
Well! and how go matters? ha! didst speak to her?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Yes, I did speak to her, and thanks to my good Tongue,
And fluent Rhetorick, a great deal, a great deal
To the purpose— hark,— thy business is done,—
She's thine, she's thine Rogue.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: But art thou in earnest? prithee do not flatter me▪
For to fall from these hopes to which thou hast rais'd me,
Would be a horrid Torture.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Peruse this Paper, and then credit me; 'tis her own
Handy-work: Sir, I assure you I could have had
A Token for you, a Ring, or a slight Bracelet
From her Arm; but that I thought 't was needless.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: A Letter, and from her? I am transported!
My best of Friends! how am I bound to thee?
I almost fear to read what's Writ within, least
The Excess of my delight should kill me.
But I must venture.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I prithee come, let's hear it.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I have such a sensible knowledge of your sufferings, That I would willingly, if it could be without prejudice of my Honour, redress e'm; But Mr. Amorous can certifie you; to whom you are infinitely oblig'd for his fidelity.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: D'e mark that Bernard?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: That 'tis not mine, but my Fathers will, that debars your coming; which also can be affirmed by your worthy Friend, sweet Mr. Amorous.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Ha! this is more then I expected, well go thy
Ways, thou art a kind hearted little Rogue,
I'le say that for thee.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: But from henceforth I desire you to have patience, and pray for an alteration, and forget not to be grateful to the deserving and noble Mr. Amorous. Your Friend Penelope.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Very well! do'st hear
What a commendable Character she gives me?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I do Sir,— a thousand suspicions gnaw my heart. reads agen.
Can be affirm'd by your worthy Friend sweet Mr. Amorous,—
'dsdeath, she loves him, 'tis plain— reads still.
(Still more!) her phrase is passionate, oh dull!
Dull Fool! to trust him with a secret to undo thee.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Come, prithee what art thou musing on?
Methinks this should make thee leap for joy;
Sing Catches, Frisk, and know no Earth to tread on:
What a Devil ayl'st thou?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Nothing Sir, nothing, only a sudden Melancholly.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Melancholly, Apox upon't, laugh it away man;
Think on thy Mistriss; thou seest I've done thy business.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Ha!—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ha! why dost thou stare on me?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: The business!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I the next visit shall finish it.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Dares he upbraid me? Sir, you shall answer this.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Answer that— d'slight he's jealous; I find it now, and now I consider on my past proceedings, it may be he has cause; he● commendations in her Letter were somewhat more then Ordinary: She addrest her self to him, but her praises were for me. ('Tis so) what a damn'd dull Rogue was I not to receive it? I'le go visit her straight, and if I find her true, Friend I shall not fear to answer your demand, though with the hazard of my Life and Fortune.

div.head: Scene II. A Tavern.
div.stage: Enter Old Winelove, Tim, Formall, Smallwit, Drawer.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: Well done Tim, bravely done Boy— Drawer, Sirrah give him t'other glass of Sack for that last action, and my little Minion of the Muses bring him but to't; let me but hear him talkt of in the Play-house, fear'd by the Bullies, and renown'd in Taverns, and I will be a Friend to thee for ever.

sp.speaker: Small.
sp.p: Your bounty Sir, has seal'd me yours: believe he shall within a little space of time be famous, and such a one as you could wish he was; he has already profited extreamly.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: But prithee let me see that Congie over again, and your posture; i'faith 't was very modish: Come Tim, prithee once again.

sp.speaker: Small.
sp.p: Look Sir in Company, take notice your Garniture, fit adjustee, and advantagiously as you can, especially if you are among Ladies; and let your Comb be ready thus for your Perriwig; whether it want or no 'tis a good posture: if you are saluted, make your Congie thus, with a start, your head bowing to your left Shoulder, as if it meant to kiss it. Very well! what think you of that Sir? did he not do that better then the last?

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: i'Faith 't was very well, Sir Formall did you see it?

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.p: Yes, but to tell you the truth, I am not for this new Fantastick way I like your ancient custom, the old way of saluting gravely, 'tis more manly; these cringing Tumblers postures I like not. Give me your method of fair salutation, a rule to grace behaviour. These new ways approv'd by being o'th' fashion, meet not my approbation.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: Old Formall, still i'faith— but mind him not Boy: I'me pleased to see thee exercise thy parts with Judgement and Discretion, Persevere Boy, Thou hast thy Fathers word for't, go on and prosper.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: And so I have Sir, never doubt, I have designs here budding in this pate of mine, that cannot chuse but prosper, but methinks my Father in Law there, that must be, gives me small encouragement.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: Oh! 'tis no matter, do not mind what he says: He! alas poor Dotard, only understood the way to purchase wealth, and make his Daughter a Fortune fit to embrace thee, that's his Master-piece.

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.p: Mr. Winelove, I hold it prudence in you first to deck his mind with internal Endowments, before you proceed to external Ornaments; for the Body, mark me Sir, is but as a Tenement, bare and unfurnisht, till the mind adorns it with her Houshold-stuff.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: Sir, he shall be adorn'd both ways; his mind shall be the business of his Tutor; his body of his Taylor; he shall be perfect, do not doubt Sir Formall.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I Sir, never doubt me, I have a spirit I assure you, perhaps a Wit too adorn'd with Endowments, such as you mention; and by my Tutors help I may in time be able to discourse with— I'le say no more— your Daughter— but let that pass.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: Why well said Tim— thy Fathers temper just.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Now I have a great mind to carp at some of his words, if I had but confidence enough to pretend to be a Critick.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: Well said again i'faith, why now I like thee; this shows thy ready Wit to apprehend; I'me pleased with this extremely.

sp.speaker: Small.
sp.p: Sir, you shall find great alteration in him within these two days; for take it from me, he has a ripening Genius, a Wit that will be poynant, and Satyrical; and some perhaps will find it.

sp.speaker: 1st. Fid.
sp.p: Will it please you Gentlemen to hear a new Lesson, or a Song A-la-mode.

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.l: S'bud you impertinent Raskal get you gone,
Or I'le so batter that Musical sconce of yours.
Song A-la-mode Quotha, I had as lieve hear a
Gibb Catt howl, and as much pleasure I take in't.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: Fie Sir Formall, this is plain rashness, beat a poor fellow for offering to divert you.

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.p: Divert me with a Pox.— Sirrah do not provoke me, but go.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.l: Stay friend, stay, this is only a little peevish
Blood he has within him— 'twill be allay'd presently.
Sir Andrew, for my sake have a little patience; why,
We came hither to be merry; 'tis a day of Jubilee,
I'faith he shall Sing.

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.p: Sir, were his Songs moral and edifying, I should dispence with the noise; but this is a lewd Rogue, that gleans up all the fragments of cast Bawdy to make Songs A-la-mode, as he calls 'um: Sirrah can you sing the battle of Mardike?

sp.speaker: 1st. Fid.
sp.p: No indeed Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.l: I told you so— not sing the Battel of Mardike?
Why thou ignorant Rogue, where hast thou bin bred?
And hussing, And puffing,
And Snuffing, And Cuffing the Spaniard;
Whose Brows have bin dy'd in a Tan-yard,
Well got Fame, a Warriours Wife.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: O brave Sir Formal.

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.l: Ah Sir, there's some matter in this now, an ill bred
Raskal, not sing the Battle of Mardike. Here's
Near a child in Banbury of 7 years old, but can
Sing the Battle of Mardike, and has it readier then
His Horn-book.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Now have I a jest for my Father in Law there, if I
Durst speak it.

sp.speaker: Small.
sp.p: What is it Sir,

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: To have told him, that no body would wonder at his
Mettle and testy humour, knowing he was born at Banbury.

sp.speaker: Small.
sp.p: Amongst the Tinkers.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ay i'gad, was not that a good one.

sp.speaker: Small.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: How now my little Mercury, what's the matter.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, 'tis a witty Varlet— but come my friend.

sp.speaker: Small.
sp.l: One of thy best Songs now, thy Newest— a Song A-la-mode—
No matter what he sayes, I'le reward thee.

lg.l: THe Age is refin'd, and the Vulgar no more are despis'd for their Talent of sense.
Good Wit, at the best is esteem'd but a jest,
A 〈◊〉 is encourag'd, Desert is supprest:
That will flourish a hundred years hence.
Fierce Criticks like Kings, rule over this Isle;
As the insolent Iudges of Wit:
And though they have none, but what is deer bought,
Yet to be judicious, they fain would be thought:
By the gleanings they get in the Pit.
Then let the precise, despair to be wise,
Let wisedom forsake his abode.
Since Wit is made none, by the Fops of the Town,
Debauches increas'd, and good fancies o'rethrown.
Chorus, By a pleasant Vice Alamode.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.l: Very well 'ifaith— hold there's an Angel for thy
Pains; now Sir Awdrew, what think of this?
Is not this better then your Doggril damn'd
Rhime, all sound, no sense. This is new, and made
By a Wit on Wit, on Critick, ah these Critick
Wits are rare Fellows.

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.l: To practise Surgery upon: To flout at the Decrees
Of Law, or Justice, to burlesque on Religion;
To make a Ballad out of Davids Psalms, and
Turn old Hopkins Meeter into Nonsense.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: Pish, you mistake me clearly.

sp.speaker: Sir. For.
sp.l: Not a jot Sir,— I've known him carp upon the
Canticles, and call 'em Canting Lectures; Laugh at
A Pious Pastor that was blind, because he told 'em,
He could show a path to lead to happiness: Ah they
Are lewd Raskals; Lord, Lord, what will this
World come to?

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.l: To dust as it 'twas of old, but believe me Sir, your
Judgment gives too harsh a sensure of 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.l: It may be so Sir, but pardon me Sir, I speak
My thoughts; I use not to dissemble, I love
Plain dealing— Drawer bring to pay.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.l: There's nothing Sir, Fye Sir Formall— put not
That forc'd expression on your Friend— so small
A thing as this should not be spoke of.

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.l: Well Sir, I know your temper, and will urge it no
Further; I'le go home and prepare my Wife and
Daughter for your Entertainment, pray be no
Stranger to my house, and let your Son come
Often, I shall expect him an hour hence, according
To your promise.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.l: Sir, he shall only go home and change his habit,
And wait on you immediatly—

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: a Complement
At parting— de'e hear—

sp.speaker: Small.
sp.p: Go Sir— the last I taught you.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Sir, when I have imbellish'd my self with external accoutrements, fit to be seen, and received by a person of your merit and grandeur, I shall not fail to imploy my internal endowments to deserve the honour to kiss the hand of your fair Daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.p: Very well Sir— I apprehend your meaning, though your phrase be somewhat odd— my welcom shall return my answer to you▪ In the mean time I take my leave.—

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: So now lets home▪ I have commanded my Taylor to make thee a Rich Suit Tim. Nay, thou shalt want for nothing Boy, be but industrious. And Mr. Smallwit, set him but forward in what he is begun; let me but hear that he is thought a Wit, and playes the Critick handsomly; the Critick, methinks the very word is modish.

sp.speaker: Small.
sp.p: He shall do this, and more I'le warrant you Sir.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: Rail at a Poets lines, and sift the meaning, especially if he be but a dabbler, a novice in the art; then let him raign tyrannically, 'twill procure Fame, whether he's right or no.

sp.speaker: Small
sp.p: He has that knack already Sir, and fear not hee'l persevere.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: Be sure thou dost Boy— but we waste the time, thou wilt be long a dressing: Come let's in.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Sir Formal told you right Daughter, you know not the tricks, nor the debauches of the Town: What Plots, what secret Jugglings are abroad, therefore I say take heed: I have, I thank my stars, been ever accounted of an immaculate Life and Conversation, and I would have that Fame descend on you, which with such great discretion I have purchast▪ but then you must deserve it.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Madam, I hope I shall, I think you yet ne're saw me guilty of any vice, could give you cause to doubt my future virtue.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Your Virtue— no, I fear not that, 'twere a sin to imagine my blood could e're rebel, Sir Formall too, though I mislike his starcht behaviour and opinion, was once a Virtuoso, and therefore think not I doubt your virtue; no, 'tis your destiny I fear.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Your fears are fruitless Madam; I ne're was yet so wedded to my will, to chuse before a tryal had made proof whether he did deserve it: Were I not sure she knows nothing of my Love to Franck Amorous, this would a little startle me▪

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.l: I do believe thee, yet give me leave to fear:
Is it not seen, a Lady whose fame for breeding
And descent, is loudly spoken of; gets a toy in her head,
Marries her Footman, and gives the Flambeau for her Crest▪
Another, charm'd with the flatteries of some smooth tongu'd seducer,
Sells her honour, and whole race, to infamy,
Ruines her self; and lastly dies a Beggar.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: These are sad Moralls Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.l: But most true; when I was young, adorn'd with blooming
Beauty, for without vanity I could so term it, I
Was admir'd, su'd to oft by many— many
With Presents woo'd me, many with Poetry, some
Would urge their merits, some their Fortunes:
Others would fight; and happy then was he that
Could procure a smile to grace his enterprize:
For I well knowing the power of my attractions,
Kept such a mean of favour 'twixt 'em all,
That none could boast his Fortune or dispair:
'Tis true, I sometimes long'd for what they offer'd,
But with a trick I had, a cunning trick,
I kept it from their knowing; at last your Father,
Who then was held a man of rare endowments,
Though now they are abused by his Customs:
So took me with his ' haviour and good parts,
For he had excellent parts— so that for his sake
I quitted all the rest.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: And left them Willowes.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.l: Every man of 'em— Therefore I say look through
The man you love: Observe his parts well,
Then view his Estate; for some there are have neither.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Neither Parts nor Estate, goodness defend me
From such a one! by your instructions Madam, I
Shall not doubt to guard my self from such
Imminent danger: Bless me, neither Parts nor Estate!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Hush, here's your Father.

sp.speaker: Sir. For.
sp.l: Sweet heart and Daughter, are you there?
That's well, go presently to your Chamber and dress
Your self, here's a Gentleman coming to see you,
Go I say.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Shall I not know his name?

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.l: No marry shall you not, let it suffice 'tis a good
Catholick name, and I approve of it,
No more questions, but obey me.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I shall Sir!— this is certainly the new Suiter
He talkt of, and heaven knows I am ill provided
For an Amour.

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.l: Come sweet heart lets go in, for I have
A world of news to tell thee.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: But little good I fear, If there be a world on't

sp.speaker: Sir. For.
sp.l: Thou'lt find there's a great deal of good in't,
I seldom fail to miss of my designes,
Come in, and be partaker.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.l: By ventring to bring you hither, I hope Sir, you
Perceive that I am not unwilling to be ungratefull,
Especially having tasted your bounty in so liberal a manner.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You over-rate▪ the triste I have given you: Pray do
Not speak of it;— Is this the Chamber?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.l: This leads to hers— have but a little patience,
With which I know Sir, I you are still provided.
I'le go and prepare her for your visit, In a more
Especial manner, because I would appear
Grateful to a person I have been so sensibly oblig'd to.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You speak what I should say, and make me blush,
I am so poor in thanks. Exit Betty.
This will in time make an excellent Bawd,
I find by her pall'd Rhetorick.
This profit is a powerful charm,
It turns and winds e'm into any form:
She's coming up with the Lady, who if I find
But loves me, I have a blessing past all recompence.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: This is the height of impudence, to bring a man, a young man too into my Chamber without my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.l: Madam, he told me he must needs speak with you
About an important concerne, and knowing your
Fathers hasty temper, was afraid to let him see him▪

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: And was there no where to bring him to, but
My Chamber? No hole, or by Corner to make
Him do pennance in for his insolence, but my
Apartment; you had best some other time
Shut him up into my Closet, till i'm a Bed.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Well thought on i'gad Madam if my rude entrance.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p:
Sir, I need no Apologies and excuses, and indeed considering it rightly, although my behaviour has been such, as not to give any one
cause, or licence to intrude into my privacies; you are not so much to be blam'd as she is.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh, nay it is well enough—

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: For you perhaps but followed your own inclination, and pursuance of the affair you say you have, but that he shou'd dare to do this.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Madam it was at my request.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: At your request! it seems then she's your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: No, 'faith Madam, not my acquaintance; for though there are some certain seasons when all women are alike to me, yet for the most part my ambition soars above the fruition of a Chambermaid.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Sir, the Character you give your self, I was sufficiently acquainted with in the last visit you made me; I hope you come about the old affair, some love Embassy from Bernard?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: From Bernard Madam? ha, ha, ha, though once to do him a Curtesie, and as a Friend I sollicited his cause, I am not ty'd to do that Office: I take no fees Madam, besides at present, Heaven be prais'd, I have other business; business of my own, would you but be pleas'd to give me a hearing.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I'me glad of that: aside.
Now if it hit but right— Sir you'l oblige me
To impart it quickly, for I'me a little in hast.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Venus for me then, now the Tale begins;
I saw the Letter you wrote to Bernard.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: It may be so.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I saw also the Commendations you gave me there.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Suppose all this.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And thereby gather that.—

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: That, what?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Command your Woman hence, and I'le declare it.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Sure 'tis no secret.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Faith but it is— a great one too.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Wait in the next room till I call for you. Exit Betty.
Now Sir be free in your Relation.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why Madam, as I was saying before, I gather by your kind Character of me to Bernard, that you are— most desperately in love with me.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: I, in love?— what shall I do?— my Blushes will betray me.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Yes Madam, and with me. Nay, do not mince the matter.
I find it by your Eyes, it must be so; y'are deeply
Ingag'd that's certain; but have a good heart
Madam, I am not cruel, I'm of a melting nature;
You may new mould, and work me even as you please;
An easie yielding temper, I, Heaven knows.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p:
'Tis very likely Sir,— yet sure 'twill hardly be
my fate to put you to the Test— I'm in Love— and with you.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Yes Madam with me, 'dsdeath is that so strange?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: You had best perswade me to't.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Faith I am endeavouring it as fast as I can.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Now I perceive the vanity of your Sex; because a Lady perhaps accidentally smiles upon you, or grants you an occasional Salute, you presently think shee's in love.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: No; but when a Lady writes to a man she do's not; and sends it by a Gentleman; and in her Letter terms the said Gentleman with the terms of sweet Mr. such a one, Dear Mr. such a one, Worthy Mr. A. and the like; what should a man think, is not this Love? 'Gad 'tis extasie, meer extasie.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Common Civility will allow of praises, especially if we think our selves oblig'd.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: But praises with such attributes Madam, There's the point. Praise is the Friend of Love: And that Woman that praises a mans parts, undoubtedly covets what she commends; as we extol that Beauty most we desire to enjoy.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: And can you think, if I did ever love you, which assure your self I do not, I could ever be brought to confess it, when you upbraid me thus; no, I look upon you as a man unworthy— base, and ill-natur'd— and perhaps unmanly— I'le curb him in a little, though my heart akes for't.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: So, I lookt for this— this fretting has confirm'd my Opinion— 'tis certain she loves me above measure; poor Soul! how her heart swells— But Madam:

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: I'le hear nothing— tax me with a light Love Sir— 'twas a word that I must tell you ill becomes a stranger, nor can our small acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Do but hear me.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: 'Tis an affront, almost past all forgiveness;
With another 'twould be counted an Insolence,
Past hopes of reconciling— but my too easie nature.—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: So now she melts agen, (this is the very
Quintessence of passion)— aside.
I know your nature Excellent as your self;
And Madam, make me not unhappy in your
Displeasure, by a few flashy words; Heaven
Knows only the Overflows of a glad Tongue,
Proud to declare your virtues.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Yes by upbraiding me.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: I upbraid thee! by Heaven I do not, and now,
(Since it must out) know that I love you, doat
On you, and dye till I enjoy you. Now
Have mercy upon me I beseech thee.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: This passion you pretend to, is so short liv'd, that
The next fair object, I doubt not, will
Reduce it to somewhat newer, and more easie to your temper.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: With other men perhaps it might— but Madam,
I am the Eternal'st Lover, the most transported
Thing, I am like Chaff before a burning Glass, and
Every glance from your eye converts me into flame.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Your comfort will be, that you have but a short time
To be tormented.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Oh, to Eternity Madam;— when I am absent from you, in
My Dreams, I shall hover over your Idea, and beget
Such an innumerable Quantity of Conceipts and Fancies,
'Twould distract another.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: No, not a Man that flies like a Hawk, at all Games,
As you do.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I Madam— well, a lye must help me out.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: O Madam! what shall we do? we are undone.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Why! what's the matter.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.l: Slipping down Stairs to see what your Father was doing,
I saw him at the door receiving from a Foot-man a Letter.
Directed Sir, to you.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: To me!

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: To you Sir; for hearing the Foot man affirm he saw you come in here, and seeing your Father about to open it, I run and snatcht it from him; and came up, leaving him pursuing me with as much hast as his Age or Gout would permit him: but for Heavens sake use some means to hide this Gentleman; for hee'l be here immediately.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: What shall I do! I'me at my Wits end.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And so am I, pox on't how unluckie's this?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Stay, I've hit of a device will certainly do,
If Betty, you play your part but well.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.l: I Madam— doubt not me, I'le do any thing to appear▪
Serviceable to this worthy and bountiful Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: 'Gad I will be bountiful to thee indeed, if
Thou canst but bring me well off now.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: What is't good Madam?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Why this Sir, you must pretend to be her Brother,
Newly come from Travel; to which purpose talk of
The Customs of some forreign Countries,
And your excuse for snatching the Letter away,
Being for your Brother, will be more plausible.
I le to my Glass, and seem to be dressing my Head—
Hark, he's coming, be sure you do it handsomly.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I'le warrant you Madam; come Sir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: This will certainly do; well, thou art a witty Devil, I'le say that for thee: I wonder whence this Letter should come, from some of my Mistresses doubtless that want company: I'le not read it till I have more leisure,— he comes.

sp.speaker: Sir For. within.
sp.p: Why Huswife, where are you? ha, are you crept into some Corner, I'le fetch you out with a vengeance, a young baggage to dare to do this.
Ha, what's here? a Man! and in my Daughters Chamber?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.l: My Brother Sir, newly return'd from Travel;
Well, and are there such rare things in Rome, say you?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Beyond expression rare— wou'd I were there
For an hour.

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.p: But where's the Letter Mistress you snatcht from me? did your Brother bid you do that? hah!

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: No indeed Sir; but fearing you would look into the secrets of our Family, which you conceive is dear to me, I took it of my own accord.

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.p: Was the Letter yours Sir?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I must presume to own it.

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.p: No presumption Sir, but pray from whence came it?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: From Italy Sir, from a good Friend of mine; and intending to visit my Sister, I bid the Porter bring it to me here.

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.p: The Porter Sir, why I had it from a Foot-man.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: 'dsdeath I shall spoil all.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: But Sir he has formerly bin a Porter, though now he is preferr'd.

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.p: Umph— like enough.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Well said i'Faith— a Guiney more for that.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: But Brother, you han't told me half enough of the rarities you have seen in your Travels.

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.p: I, come Sir, pray let's hear some of the wonders at Rome, and other places, the story must needs be pleasing; pray make a brief description.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: 'Zounds what shall I do now? for I know nothing of Rome but the name; but 'tmay be he's as ignorant as I, and then I am warm enough— Why Sir, as to the Climate, 'tis much about the temper 'twas of old, hottish and dry, the Houses largely built, and uniform; the people of divers Complexions, and much given to Ease, more indeed then to Devotion; a pleasant Country Sir, and for the most part fruitful.

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.p: It was when I was there; but 'tis so long since, that by my Faith I have almost forgot it; well Sir, and how looks the Vatican? does he stand stoutly still? and do's he still triumph in his Age and Excellence?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: The Vatican! what a Devil's that?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Now is he a pumping: Madam, 'tis a damn'd hard word, that I cannot help him for my life.

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.l: Do's he still hold his Head above the rest?
And want no Succour, nor no Aid to help him;
He has bin an old Standard, but a brave one.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: This must certainly be the Pope he means, and calls by some
Nick-name.

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.p: Come pray Sir tell me, you're too slow in answer.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Now do I sweat for him.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I'gad I'le venture on't: why faith he do's very bravely still, and is very much renown'd in Italy; but there has lately happen'd a disaster.

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.p: What's that good Sir?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why Sir he has within these few Months bin troubled with a violent— and very damnable Fit of the Stone.

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.p: What say you Sir?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And hardly scap'd with life Sir, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, the Vatican troubled with the Stone: madness i'th height; but hark you Sir, perhaps you mean, there ha's bin a Hurricane of late that has damag'd some of her Turret, and overthrown some superfluous Stones, whose strength, age had decay'd: mean you not so Sir?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: So Sir, yes Sir, what a Devil should I mean else: well I'le make hast away, least he should ask any more questions. Sir, Your humble Servant: Dear Sister, adieu; I'le wait on you again at my next leisure, Vatican with a Pox, a Curse of my dull pate.

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.p: A witty understanding man I'le warrant him; how wittily he Joak'd upon me. Come Daughter lets go down, by this the Gentleman is ready to come, who, I'le assure you, is first, accomplish'd with parts to your desire, and not mine; Secondly, with wealth to my desire, though not yours, and I command you to use him well, for believe,
sp.l: No blessing, but a discontent she owns,
Whose want of duty reaps her Fathers frowns.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: SO, I have got away with much ado; Impudence was, I must needs confess, my great Friend, or else I had never bin able to hold out against that Eternal old Fellow, who would have ply'd me with new questions; but now to my Letter, I hope 'tis from some new rare Creature in Love with me, and sent this to point an assignation. reads.

body.p: Since you have bin base and treacherous, you ought in reason to expect the reward of baseness and falshood; know therefore, that being betray'd, me and my injury's insupportable, till reveng'd: I desire you to meet me in the plain Field below Lambs-Conduit, about 6 this Afternoon, without a second, to render satisfaction; and assure your self, though your treachery has made me miserable, my action shall speak me brave and generous,

sp.p: Was ever hopes so frustrated? this is a Challenge, and o' my Conscience if I should survey my self throughly, I am not provided for't. This damn'd Custom of Wenching has made me as damn'd a Coward, as a Bully that fights for hire, (meet me in the plain Field below Lambs-Conduit) and 'gad I will meet thee there, come what will, since I am invited. I had Courage once, and have yet I hope some grains: if I am kill'd I have the fewer sins to answer for; and if I live, I've the longer time to repent; at 6 a Clock, and now it wants of 5, well, I'le first go dispatch a small affair, and then have at him.
sp.l: Men only live to further fate's design,
'Twas Plato's moral once, but now 'tis mine.

div.head: Scene II.
div.stage: Enter Sir Formall, Lady Ancient, Tim, Smallwit, Betty, Mrs. Penelope

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.p: Once more y'are welcome Sir; and pray excuse me if I am not altogether Ceremonious as some, that love the mode, and cherish vanity: my humour is my Law Sir, therefore pray excuse me. But where's your Father?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Sir, he's gone to walk in the Fields, the old Gentleman loves Air.

sp.speaker: Lady An.
sp.p: Sir, though Sir Formall hold it unnecessary to express the welcom of a person of merit in descent, and modish phrases; yet there are some who understand the behaviour fit to be us'd on such Occasions: Sir! your presence is an honour to our House.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Madam, Sir Formall knows that I desire to appear no stranger; I have, I thank my Fortune, so much knowledge of the Town, not to let modesty obscure good meaning; I know what's Courtly Madam, and approve it.

div.stage: Enter a Lawyer with a Deed.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Sir, here's the Deed: wilt please you to peruse it?

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.p: I come, Sweet-heart, prithee thy Ear a little.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Indeed Sir I think it very fine.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Madam, it would have bin so, had it bin well order'd; but this damn'd Son of a Whore Taylor had made it too narrow in the Breast; the Buttons are not half big enough neither.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Methinks they're very well Sir; however, your grateful person, were they ill made, would make e'm Comely.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Why 'faith Madam as you say, a graceful person do's much, very much, the well spreading of the Shoulders, and straightness, adds much to the shape; and yet without the posture, the modish August Garb, and Courtly mean, the shape is nothing.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: What an Idol do's this fellow make of himself?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Madam take it from me, 'tis a hard matter to see a man demean himself with Judgement, the Town's a strenger to't— how do I do this? ha—

sp.speaker: Small.
sp.p: Exceeding well Sir, but forward.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: There are indeed a sort of empty fellows, that have pretences that would seem to know the Essence of good Carriage▪ but search e'm throughly,— far, far short on't.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Some such there are indeed Sir, but others that though they have not that Modish mean you speak of, may have Wit which may supply the others want.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Wit, Madam,— why there's a famine on't; but now alas the times are Metamorphos'd, there's no wit stirring.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Sir, methinks there has been a great many very witty Playes come out lately.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
Ah,— dull, dull, Madam,— dull to the tenth degree, nothing but prolix phrases, and bombast, hardly a word of sense, or fancy in 'em; our Poets now take it from me Madam, have nothing of conceit: One writes of Rural Wit bubbled by Carmen, another of Inchantments, Bears and Monsters, and such a coil they keep with their new fancies,
that wit and sense are lost, quite lost, abolish't; nothing remains but the meer dregs of fancy; you may believe me Madam.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Sir, I'le not presume to question it, or doubt the truth of what you say, though I confess it seems a little strange.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I grant it may Madam, and by the way let me tell you, another would not have found it out; I have I thank my stars, some certain guifts which others want; 'tis as Providence decree's, every one has his Talent.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: But not alike, I hope Sir.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: No Madam, I hope to see that: the truth is, I love to be free, and perhaps sityrical in my opinion, and I doubt not but you are acquainted with the mode, and know what becomes a Gentleman; for faith should we not sometimes dive into the secrets of Wit, and reprove mistakes, these Rascally Poets would grow insolent, there would be no living for 'em, we should be so perpetually tormented with Lampoons; but 'gad I cramp the Rascals.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Would thou wert crampt and gag'd, so I were rid of thee.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: You'd laugh to see how afraid they are of me, to'ther day Madam, I went to see a Play, and sitting 'mongst the rest in the Wits Corner; I know not what, but somewhat I mislik't, and raised a hiss, which presently was seconded by all the Wits: But to see the poor fellow the Poet, peep out between the Scenes, and shake his empty head, to see his Ten Months labour so rewarded, would have made you die with Laughter, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Small.
sp.p: In this Madam, you rather condemn my Judgment, then excuse your want of merit. But give me leave to tell you, if I have any Wit, you are a woman of great parts. Do you see that Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Yes Sir, methinks a man of Excellent good Parts.

sp.speaker: Small.
sp.p: He is so, yet this— this Modish Gallant that's now so brisk and ayrie, did I within these three dayes draw out of a lump of ignorance, a wretched lump, a thing of nothing mould, stampt and fram'd him as you see, and of a Coxcomb, changd'd him to a Courtier, a Modish fellow, and the Son of Fortune— Sir, your Verses, you forget that—

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
Hush, I warrant thee— Madam, to let you see, that what I speak is Reason, you shall your self be judge; I have a Copy of Verses here, given me by one of the Poets, who desir'd my opinion of 'em— ah, here they are Madam— I'le read 'em to you— hum, 'tis an Encomium on his Mistress.
Best of thy Sex, and brighter then the Moon
At her full Glory, or the Sun at Noon:
Sweet as a bed of Roses, far above▪
All that ever yet pretend to Love.
For thou appear'st, as if thou would perswade
Men to believe, for thee, Love first was made.
Or that the bliss of nature should contest
With the delightful Lodging of thy breast.
Zealots release the blessings heapt above
Of lasting Raptures, and immortal Love.
But Iove, and all his Crowd of joyes should be
Dispis'd and slighted for a tast of thee.
This and a great deal more such stuffe is here, such— much— 'gad I am e'en sick to read it.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Methinks they are very well Sir, only a little too full of rapture, and flattery— but that may be born withall.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Well Madam, I see your design, ha, ha, ha, to bantor the poor fellow:— but— 'tdo, what answer do you think I made,— what de'e think I did with'em?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Why, I suppose Sir, you spoke indifferently, and the less critically because you intended to encourage him.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Encourage him? 'dsdeath encourage a Poet, I'de sooner do't to a Cutpurse, and more good I shall get by him— no Madam, I damn'd it— damn'd it to the Center.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: But Sir, you had no reason for't, the verses did not deserve it.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Pish— that's no matter, it quell'd the Rascalls hopes, why should I have encouraged him, and prais'd what he had writ, 'tis ten to one within this twelve months, he would have writ a Play, and made a Character of me, but 'gad I dash't his hopes, his Muse, and he will hardly be reconcil'd this month through the fright I put him in.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Well, this is the most intollerable Fop, that ever I saw, there's no enduring him.

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.p: And let me have that Mannor too incerted as a Covenant for repairs, and fail not on't tomorrow.
Pray Sir, give your excuse, 'tis only a little parcel of Land which I determine for my Daughters Joynture— but come lets in to Dinner, by this time 'tis ready— and once more welcome to my house.

sp.speaker: Small.
sp.p: I am too poor in thanks.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I am too poor in thanks Sir; softly you Rogue—

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.p: Ah not poor in any thing, good Mr. Winelove, 'faith I do not like it— but come, no Ceremony I beseech you, but to Dinner.

div.head: SCENE III. Landskip.
div.stage: Enter Bernard and Frank to Fight.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: The cause of my quarrel Sir, you cannot be ignorant of, knowing who I am, and how you have betrayed me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: My answer lyes in this, not in my words, come, come, you are too tedious.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: O this shews your courage Sir, but believe you shall have sighting work enough e're I kill yee, as certainly I shall before we part.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why, then the Surgeon's paid Sir, come we lose time; then once more at you Sir.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: How now what's here, Swords drawn and Fighting; ah, that my Tim. were here now, to put in for a third man, but I'le try what I can do to part 'em— Gentlemen hold, hold, you've fought enough, hold, hold, I say.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Hark Reverend Sir, 'twill become your gravity to retire a while, and not disturb us, least that portly shape of yours be discommoded— pox on him, h'as given me another thinking while.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: Faith he sayes true, I was too rash, well Gentlemen, since you will have it so, fight it out bravely, and I'le stand by, and see fair play on both sides.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You see your fortune Sir.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Yes, and contemn'd it, and my life too, seeing 'tis at thy mercy.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You will do well to cherish it, for all that Sir.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: A brave fellow this, and I'le warrant a right Courtier, he has the true way on't, now would I give twenty pound my Tim. were here.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Ah Sir, to insult I know, is Customary.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: To insult?— to let thee see how far I am from it, there, there's thy Sword again, and give me thy hand, I could wish I could as easily give back thy Mistress; but our Stars would have it otherwise; thou knowest we can't appoint our own destinies; besides thou hast another Mistress, and two at once is too much in reason for any one man.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: 'Tis true, I have another Mistress perhaps fairer then 'tother, whom I intend to visit as soon as this hurt Arm is drest; but what excuses can you bring from that?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Why, 'faith not many— but dost hear, shall I carry commendations from thee to her too, hah?— Prithee let me.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: No, no, Sir, my own Rhetorick henceforth shall serve, but to let you see I have a sense of generosity, as well as baseness, I'le quit the place, and henceforth do as my honour shall direct me, and not passion, and if there be a way for friendship left, I'le find it, if not, 'tis but adventring another skirmish, and then perhaps I shall be as loath to take a Wife, as you to give it.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: By Iuno, that's a brave fellow too— ah, he's gone Sir, you have sent him packing— 'faith you fought it bravely, I never saw a Duel fought with better Judgement; are you not hurt Sir?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I think not, I feel nothing.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p:
Your Antagonist, believe me, was a shrewd fellow, and
saith once I thought would have damag'd you, your point being born too low, but you recovered it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I Sir, I did so.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: And bravely Sir, you did in doing so; when I was of your years I had some fame myself for Duelling— ah, I have seen the time when I have come into the field with Courage, travers'd my ground, fought and passado'd briskly, and as simply as I now stand here, been victor.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: 'Tis very likely Sir, this is the most impertinent old fellow I ever saw, he will enter into discourse whether I will or no— Sir, your Servant, I am a little in haste.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: Pray Sir, a word more, I have a little business with you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Umph— I am of late grown a man of more business then ever I design'd myself. Pray Sir, what is it quickly? for some present Occasions call me hence.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: Shall I then Sir, desire the favour of you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Sir, Any favour, be but brief, and tell it.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: I shall Sir, 'tis a small matter, a very small matter, only to know whether you are indebted to any one, or to be more plain, whether you owe any money?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Money Sir? Sir, that's a strange question, nor know I at present how to resolve it.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: Doubt not my meaning good, nor conceit I question this to draw you into danger, 'faith I do not.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Why then Sir, know I am a Gentleman, and have means large enough to pay my debts if they were ten times doubled, methinks you might have guess'd that by my outside without questioning. What is't.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: Now I come to you Sir— I have a Son my Heir, for whom I have these 5 and 50 years been scraping an Estate, he now is grown up to maturity, and 'faith to speak freely of him, is a youth of rare endowments, and pregnant Wit Sir, and admired Fancy.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Sir, being your Son, it were a sin to doubt it.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: Now Sir, I see you are a man of parts, one that the Town takes notice of; you can talk well, fight well, sing well, Court your Miss in Rhime, with any Modish Bully of 'em all.

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: Ah, your servant Sir, not I 'faith.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: Sir, I have heard you fam'd— talkt of, and wondred at, Constables fear you, Bayliffs creep into Corners, and our witty dabbling Poets of the time, cry, yonder's Amorous, plague of his Criticisms.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You are pleas'd to lay this on me Sir,— what a devil will this come to?

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: All this confess'd, then he that has the honour to keep you company, must needs be very happy; and Sir, as my Son is the happiness of my Life, and his well doing my chief comfort, it is my earnest request to you.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: To be his Tutor, and teach him the Town Virtues.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: No Sir, not his Tutor, far be that dishonour from you, besides, he has a Tutor already, a pretty quibbling Fellow that has taught him very well: But Sir, to be of your acquaintance, would make him for ever— and Sir, to gratifie you, command my Estate. You are a young-man, and perhaps by extraordinary Expences, are sometimes out of Money, I have some Bags to spare Sir, pray make use of 'em: My Money, Houses, Land, Estate is at your Service, be but acquainted with my Son Sir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: This is unlookt for Fortune— But 'tis such a good natur'd old Fool, that methinks 'tis pitty to bubble him. Sir, for your proffers, I return you thanks, and assure your self what lyes in me to serve you, or your Son, shall be done without further Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: Why, I thank you— heartily thank you.— Tim. thou art made for ever. Sir, he is hard by at a Friends house of mine, whose Daughter he is to marry.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Hard by, say you Sir? pray who is't.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: An old acquaintance Sir, one Sir Formall Ancient.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Sir Formall Ancient.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: Ay Sir, and his Daughter my Strippling is to marry, 'tis already concluded on.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: My Mistress by Heaven, and I consider on't, this must needs be the Sutor she told me of: This was a happy discovery, for I question not but I shall go near to forbid the banes. Sir, I'le wait on you thither.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: With all my heart Sir, I was just going to request it of you. So I shall work him rarely.

He is certainly the fit'st Companionin the world for Tim; he knows the Town tricks, all the humours, fashions, has all new Songs by heart, knows with a grace how to accost a Wench, Strut and talk Bawdy, and then he looks with so compos'd a shape, as he were only made to be a Wencher.— Old Peter rest contented, all's now finish'd, thy Son shall be aspark, and thou be happy, happy as thou couldst wish: well, I'le follow him, and once more refresh his memory, repeat his promise.
sp.l: Then triumph in my Fate; this being done,
And boast the best of Criticks was my Son.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: WIll you not tell me who you fought with; methinks if you had any Love for me, you should not let me ask so often, prithee tell.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Why, I tell thee I do not know him, he's one that belongs to the Town; a wretched Fellow that hardly knows himself, and I suppose was one hir'd to challenge me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: In some Ladies Quarrel, I'le lay my life.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Pish, What Lady? I know no Lady, nor like none but thee; Come, Come, this fruitless Jealousie's still to be avoided, assure thy self I Love thee, only thee.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why, are you then so hasty to be gone? You never come to Visit me, but as if your minutes came too fast upon you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: You rack your self with doubts, and think I slight you, when 'tis my chief endeavour how to please you; but for my absence at present, 'tis requir'd on earnest business, and believe nothing but earnest business, great and profitable could take me from thee; but have a little Patience, and I'le be with thee instantly.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well, there must be something more in the wind then he is willing to acknowledge; but at leisure I will wheedle the secret from him, and then provide for my self as occasion serves.

div.head: Scene II. Hall.
div.stage: Enter Tim, Lady Ancient, Penelope, Betty.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Sir, though I see in your Phrases a great deal of Wit and Gallantry; yet if I may presume, you are too poynant, your fancy flowes to so extream a deluge, as 'twould o'rewhelm the Age: You look Sir, too sharply into the nature of things, and are, I doubt not, a great Philosopher; but Sir—

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: A Philosopher— what a pox is that?— Now this Rogue my Tutor hath left me alone, and I shall be mir'd immediatly— but what Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: But in truth Sir I think you are a little too Satyrical in your Opinion, and though 'tis probable you have read Alexander Ross: Who let me tell you was a great Wit, as any in his time, according to my simple Judgement, a very Excellent Fellow,— What think you of him Sir?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Of who Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Alexander Ross.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Alexander Ross, the Devil Ross him, I'm sure he broke my head once at School— a very Shrewd Fellow indeed, and to my knowledge a great Scholar, I have try'd him often.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: The Fool has come off a great deal better then I expected.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Yet though he was a Critick, and a Scholar, he gave all publick notice, Printed his Books Cum Privilegio, and gave convincing Reasons for what he did: And Sir, would you do so?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Reasons Madam, alas you wroung your Judgment; you talk at the old rate of fifty three, when the World flourisht in its ignorance, when Wealthy Blades with Velvet Cloakes through lin'd, Booted and Spurr'd, and almost hid in Ruff; would Argue out whole hours with Sense and Reasons, and in Discourse pretend to expound it too: But now the Worlds grown wise, its grown out of fashion, few men give Reasons for what they do, at least few Witty men.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Then Sir, since you have no Reasons for your Criticisms, good Nature should oblige you to be favourable.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Who I!— 'faith Madam, I am,— for were I not favourable, many a poor Fellow about Town would be undone.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: 'Tis well Impudence is Modish, thou wert else to my knowledge a very miserable Fellow. Prithee Betty, what think'st thou of him.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Truly Madam, he suffers in my Censure equal with your Ladyships, and I think him to be a bundle of Vanity; otherwise called a Fop in Extraordinary.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Do's your Ladiship delight in Songs? I'le sing you one or two of mine own Penning.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Oh! extreamly Sir, and now I think on't, I had a Song given me yesterday of a Kinsman of mine's Penning, Betty can sing it; you shall hear it Sir, and I pray you give me your Opinion of it.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: With all my heart Madam, and afterwards you shall hear mine.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: The Tune was Set Sir, by a very good Friend of his, one Mr. Smith, and late Composer to the Kings Play-house.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
Who Bob! a very Excellent Fellow Madam, believe me, and one the Town Misses very much to my knowledge; for now a dayes what ever is the matter with 'em, I know not, but we have such Tunes, such lowsy lamentable Tunes, that 'twould make one forswear all Musick, Maiden Fair, or the the Kings Delight, are incomparable to some of
these we have now. 'Tis true the Theater Musick is something tollerable, because 'tis for their Credit; but otherwise—

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Sir, I see you are a great Judge;— Come Betty the Song: Pray observe Sir, 'tis a little wanton, that's all the fault I know in it.

lg.l: I found my Caelia one night undrest,
a precious Banquet for languishing Love,
the charming object a flame increast,
which never, ah never, till then I prov'd;
her delicate skin, and starry eye,
made me a secret bliss pursue,
but with her soft hand she still put it by, and cry'd,
Fie Amintor what would you do?
Her words and blushes so fir'd my heart,
I pull'd her to me and clasp'd her around,
And though with Cunning she play'd her part:
Yet fainter, and fainter, her threats I found.
But when I least thought on her, least I desir'd,
My Love a forbearance should allow,
A touch of her hand, my heart so inspir'd:
My Passion was melted I know not how.
Which when fair Caelia's quick eye perceiv'd,
And found by my calmness my passions decay,
Her Fate she inwardly seem'd to grieve:
That Fool'd her, and Cool'd her so base away.
She sigh'd and look'd pale to see me dull,
And in her heart, this oath she swore,
She never again would slight an address:
Nor the Critical minute refuse no more.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Now Sir, how de'e like it?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: 'Ifaith a pretty Song, and a great deal of Wit in't, but I am confident it won't take.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Why Sir?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: It wants a little more of that same in it: Those wrappings in Clean Linnen, it should have appeared naked as 'twas meant; To be plain with you Madam, nothing but Bawdy— down-right,— rank Bawdy will do now, nor hardly that neither, if it have not some new meaning.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Fye Sir, this is too Satyrical.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Not at all Madam— 'tis a lewd Age, a very Pocky, Pitiful, Age, and must be abus'd, or know no Reformation.

div.stage: Enter Sir Formal, Old Wine, Frank.

sp.speaker: Sir For.
sp.p: Here he is Sir, my Wife and Daughter with him, close at the business Sir you see he looses no time.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: This Sir is he,— Tim, pray know this Gentleman, a worthy person, and one has done me great Honour.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: 'Dsheart this is the Fool I bubbled one day at Spearings, I must smooth him with a Complement for fear of discovery.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Sir, if I mistake not, I had the honour to see you once before, but now am proud that Fortune has been so kind as to grace me with this second interview.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Sir, 'twas a Happiness I confess unexpected that brought me into your Company, and this second chance has confirmed the Obligation, and made me infinitely a debtor.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Franck Amorous! and in the Company of my Father! this amazes me: Betty, you must follow still the old humour, and call him Brother, Last my Father should discover our last Plot.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: O Madam never fear his discovery, I'le warrant you I'le secure him— dear Brother—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Sister, how dost thou? I ha' not seen thee a good while,— but business must excuse all.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Is she your Sister Sir?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Yes Sir, and the best of 'em I'le assure you— but mum, more of that hereafter.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Well Sir, I come indifferent near you, for this Lady here is to be my Wife.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Say you so Sir? nay then on your account I may presume to Salute her, without further Ceremony;
Your Wife say you Sir?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Faith even so Sir, the Sisters have decreed it.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You're happy Sir, but pray, how many Months Courtship was your purchase?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Though this seems to be a Modish Fellow, yet by his Discourse, he seems to know little of the Town Courtship. Sir,— Why I never Courted her in my life, Damme, methinks a mans Parts and Perfections may do it without Courtship: But Sir, I see you are ignorant of the new way of address.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I am in troth Sir.

sp.speaker: Old Wine.
sp.p: Tim, come hither.

sp.speaker: Frank.
